question: In which northern English town does the Northern Irish comedian who hosted a long-running ITV variety series in the 1980s currently reside?
llm_answer: The context does not specify the current town of residence for Jimmy Cricket, the Northern Irish comedian who hosted the 1980s ITV variety series "And There's More."

context.text: joined as co-anchor of the previously single-headed main evening programme. Burns announced in April 2011 that he would be retiring from the role but would move on to present a Sunday morning show on BBC Radio Manchester and BBC Radio Lancashire in September 2011, with his last TV bulletin broadcast on 30 September.  He was the voice of "The Chain" feature and other features on the Radcliffe & Maconie show on BBC Radio 6 Music . He appears as a guest on the show when The Chain reaches a significant milestone, for example, for the 5,000th (musically based) item on 3 March 2015 which was the single " Dancing Queen " by ABBA . In 2013, Burns retired after stepping down from his radio show. Personal life Burns is married to Sheelagh and has a daughter and a stepson from his wife's first marriage. He lives in Hale, Greater Manchester . He is the second cousin of English singer/songwriter Ed Sheeran . References External links Gordon Burns at IMDb Gordon at Wallace High school

James Mulgrew (born 17 October 1945), known professionally as Jimmy Cricket , is a Northern Irish comedian. He first came to prominence as a comedian in the 1970s and has had his own shows on television and radio. Early life and career Cricket was born in Cookstown, County Tyrone , Northern Ireland, and left school at 16. He spent the next two years working in a betting shop , before spending the summer of 1966 working as a Red Coat in Butlins Holiday camp at Mosney , County Meath . He spent the following two summers at the Butlins in Clacton , Essex . By the early 1970s he was living in Stockport . From 1972 he worked at the Pontins holiday camps in Southport and Morecambe . He returned to Clacton-on-Sea in 2006 to star in the eight-week summer show Summer Special at the West Cliff Theatre . Cricket has toured in the UK with other artists such as The Osmonds , Brotherhood of Man , Gerry and the Pacemakers . He has also toured in comedy themed shows with Cannon and Ball , Paul Daniels , Frank Carson and The Krankies . In 2022 he toured with Leah Bell in the "Right Royal Knees Up Show" for the Queen's Platinum Jubilee . Television and radio He was given his own four television series on a show called And There's More (named after his best-known catchphrase), produced by Central Television (also notable for including the first TV appearance by Rory Bremner ). He also had his own radio series for BBC Radio 2 called Jimmy's Cricket Team , written by Eddie Braben and starring Peter Goodwright , Bill Pertwee and Noreen Kershaw . He featured in The Krankies Klub alongside the Krankies and Bobby Davro . He has appeared in numerous Royal Variety Shows . He has featured on numerous occasions on the BBC TVs long running TV show The Good Old Days Cricket appeared on Bullseye in 1984, scoring 125 with nine darts for charity. He told Tony at the oche he forgot to add 60, saying ‘and there’s more’; Tony pretended he forgot and added the 60 to give a total of 185. Cricket was the subject of This Is Your Life in 1987 when he was surprised by Eamonn Andrews in central London - the last regular edition of the programme to be broadcast with Andrews as presenter.  Cricket was one of a number of performers to appear in the video for the 2007 Comic Relief single, a cover of The Proclaimers ' song " I'm Gonna Be (500 Miles) " by Matt Lucas as Andy Pipkin and Peter Kay as Brian Potter . Style Cricket's humour is entirely clean. A popular theme of his comedy is Irish logic , and the ubiquitous letter from his "Mammy". He almost always appears in his trademark outfit of

Gordon Henry Burns (born 10 June 1942) is a Northern Irish retired journalist and broadcaster. He was the host of The Krypton Factor for its original 18-year run (1977–1995) and was the chief anchorman for the BBC regional news programme North West Tonight from January 1997 to October 2011. In November 2011, he moved back to Belfast where he was born. Due to Burns' work commitments with Granada Television on programmes such as World in Action and Granada Reports and later BBC Manchester for North West Tonight , he resided in Manchester for over thirty years. He most recently hosted a Sunday morning radio show for BBC Radio Manchester and BBC Radio Lancashire . Early life Burns was born in Wellington Park, in Belfast. When he was a child his family moved to Kent , where he attended the local primary school and then went to Dulwich College in London. The family then returned to live at Belfast's Belmont Road, where Burns attended Campbell College . Career He began his journalism career working on the Belfast Telegraph and worked on BBC radio's long-running Sports Report before joining Ulster Television as a sports editor and programme producer in 1967. Two years later, Burns began presenting the nightly news programme UTV Reports , first as a stand-in for regular frontman David Mahlowe and later as a chief anchor, during the early stages of The Troubles . In 1973, Burns joined Granada Television to anchor their nightly news programme Granada Reports and to work on the station's current affairs output, including World in Action . In September 1976 he presented an edition of Granada's Friday night football preview programme Kick Off , in which he was covering for the regular presenter Gerald Sinstadt .  Burns's national profile began with his association of ITV 's game show The Krypton Factor which he presented for eighteen years from 1977 to 1995. He was the presenter of Password for Ulster Television , one of that company's few programmes to be shown throughout the ITV network and also hosted a Searchline segment in several series of LWT 's Surprise Surprise . During the 1980s Burns also reported from the political party conferences for the ITV network, and presented the Channel 4 current affairs series Irish Angle . In the early 1990s he presented two parlour game shows for the BBC: A Word in Your Ear and Relatively Speaking . He has also appeared as a guest on Noel's House Party .  From 1997 to 2011, Burns presented North West Tonight , alongside its shorter lunchtime version, North West Today . In 2007, Ranvir Singh joined as co-anchor of the previously single-headed main evening programme. Burns announced in April 2011 that he would be retiring from the role but would move on to present a Sunday morning show on BBC Radio Manchester and BBC Radio Lancashire in September 2011, with his last TV bulletin broadcast on

Cedric Antonio Kyles (born April 24, 1964), known professionally as Cedric the Entertainer , is an American stand-up comedian, actor and television host. He hosted BET 's ComicView during the 1993–1994 season and Def Comedy Jam in 1995. He is best known for co-starring with Steve Harvey on The WB sitcom The Steve Harvey Show , as one of The Original Kings of Comedy , and for starring as Eddie Walker in Barbershop . He starred in the TV Land original series The Soul Man , which aired from 2012–16 and hosted the 12th season of the daytime version of Who Wants to Be a Millionaire from 2013–14 . He has also done voice work for Ice Age , the Madagascar film series, Charlotte's Web , Planes and Planes: Fire & Rescue . He currently stars on the CBS sitcom The Neighborhood . In 2019, he received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame . Early life Cedric was born on April 24, 1964, in Jefferson City, Missouri , the son of Rosetta (née Boyce), a schoolteacher, and Kittrell Kyles, an employee of the Missouri Pacific Railroad . He has a younger sister, Sharita Kyles Wilson, a communications professor at Pepperdine University in Malibu, California . Cedric was raised in Caruthersville, Missouri , but after junior high school he moved to Berkeley, Missouri , a northern suburb of St. Louis . He is a graduate of Berkeley High School . Cedric majored in mass communication at Southeast Missouri State University and worked as a State Farm Insurance claims adjuster and substitute high school teacher before becoming a full-time comedian. He is a member of Kappa Alpha Psi . Career Cedric's stage name came about when he felt that his real name, Cedric Kyles, sounded too formal. Inspired by an entertainer named Kodak, he came up with the name "Cheerio", but received a cease and desist letter from General Mills over their cereal Cheerios . He settled on his stage name when someone introduced him as "an entertainer, Cedric the entertainer" and the name stuck. After appearing on It's Showtime at the Apollo in 1992, Cedric hosted BET 's ComicView during the 1993–1994 season, and Def Comedy Jam in 1995. He then moved into acting, auditioning for and receiving his first-ever role as The Cowardly Lion in the 1995 Apollo Theater Revival of The Wiz . He expanded his career by playing Steve Harvey 's friend Cedric Jackie Robinson on The Steve Harvey Show . While his acting career grew, Cedric continued to perform stand-up comedy and traveled the country as one of the Kings of Comedy headliners with Steve Harvey, D. L. Hughley and Bernie Mac . The act was later made into

Kyle Joseph George Lafferty (born 16 September 1987) is a Northern Irish professional footballer who plays as a striker for West of Scotland League Premier Division side Johnstone Burgh . Lafferty began his professional career with English side Burnley , where he made 89 appearances. He signed for Rangers in 2008 for £3.25 million and won three Scottish Premier League titles, the Scottish Cup once and the Scottish League Cup twice with the club. In 2012 Lafferty chose not to transfer over to the new company, moving to Switzerland's FC Sion . He signed for Serie B club Palermo in 2013 and led them to promotion as champions in his only season before joining Norwich City . He spent time on loan with Turkish club Çaykur Rizespor and back in England with Birmingham City . After just over a year back in Scotland with Heart of Midlothian , Lafferty re-signed for Rangers in August 2018, and he has since had short spells with Sarpsborg 08 , Sunderland , Reggina , Kilmarnock and Anorthosis Famagusta . In January 2022, he returned to Kilmarnock , joining the club for the second time. He would then return to his native Northern Ireland to play for Linfield for a short while, before dropping down to the Scottish seventh tier to play for Johnstone Burgh . He made his first international appearance for Northern Ireland in 2006 and has more than 80 caps, representing the team at UEFA Euro 2016 . With 20 goals he is the team's second highest scorer of all time, behind former strike partner David Healy on 36. Club career Burnley In 2004, Lafferty signed a youth team apprenticeship with Championship club Burnley . The following season saw him begin to make an impression upon the Burnley first team. He made his debut during a 2–1 away league defeat to Crewe Alexandra on 6 August 2005, coming on as an 89th-minute substitute for Garreth O'Connor . In January 2006, Lafferty joined Darlington on loan. He went on to make nine appearances and net three goals for the club, including a scoring debut against Notts County on 7 January. He returned to Burnley in February 2007. He scored his first senior goal for Burnley against Luton Town , netting the equaliser for a 1–1 draw on 30 April 2006. Lafferty played 89 times and scored 10 goals during his time at Burnley. Rangers On 16 June 2008, Burnley accepted a bid from Rangers of £3 million plus Alan Gow but talks with Gow over his move to Turf Moor broke down. Lafferty moved to Rangers on 19 June after the transfer offer was readjusted to write Gow out of the deal. He

Garth Ennis (born 16 January 1970) is a Northern Irish-American comics writer, best known for his acclaimed run on the Vertigo series Hellblazer , his own Vertigo creation Preacher with artist Steve Dillon , his nine-year run on Marvel Comics ' Punisher franchise, and The Boys with artist Darick Robertson . He has collaborated with artists such as Dillon and Glenn Fabry on Preacher , John McCrea on Hitman , Marc Silvestri on The Darkness , and Carlos Ezquerra on both Preacher and Hitman . His work has won him recognition in the comics industry, including nominations for the Comics Buyer's Guide Award for Favorite Writer in 1997, 1998, 1999, and 2000. Like his inspiration, Alan Moore , he is a promoter of left-liberal ideas , for which he has received numerous awards and recognition from specialised British and American publications and organisations, such as the UK Comic Art Award and the Comics Buyer's Guide Fan Awards . Early life Ennis was born in Holywood , a suburb of Belfast , Northern Ireland. Raised with no religion , Ennis's first exposure to the idea of God was as a six-year-old in primary school. Ennis's teacher told the class that God was a being who could see inside their hearts, was always around them, and would ultimately reward or punish them. Ennis described the idea as bewildering, strange and terrifying. He later used this experience in his comic book series Preacher , whose protagonist is slapped after telling his grandmother that he finds the concept of God "scary". Although the fictional violence in that story was not reflected in Ennis's real-life upbringing, his classmates later reassured each other that they all loved God, though Ennis said, "I think I hate him." Ennis later asked his mother about God, and when she asked him what he thought about the idea, Ennis responded, "It sounds kind of stupid," a statement the adult Ennis clarified was meant to mask his fear. His mother's response was, "Well, there you are, then." In 1980, Ennis won second place in the Young Ornithologist's Club 's Young Ornithologist of the Year competition in the 10-12 age bracket. In 1987, Ennis befriended artist John McCrea while shopping at the first comic book specialty shop in Belfast , which had been opened by McCrea and another friend. Ennis would later ask McCrea to illustrate his first professional comics project. It was here that Ennis first met comics writer Alan Moore , who advised him to focus on creator-owned work rather than letting comic companies take ownership of his intellectual property. Career UK work Ennis began his comic-writing career on his nineteenth birthday in 1989, with the series Troubled Souls in the British anthology Crisis . Illustrated by Ennis's friend John McCrea , as living in Northern Ireland meant he

The Northern Cheyenne Tribe of the Northern Cheyenne Indian Reservation ( Cheyenne : Tsėhéstáno ) is the federally recognized Northern Cheyenne tribe and a Plains tribe . The Northern Cheyenne Indian Reservation is reservation located in southeastern Montana , that is approximately 690 square miles (1,800 km 2 ) large. It is home to approximately 6,000 Cheyenne people. The reservation is bounded on the east by the Tongue River and on the west by the Crow Reservation . There are small parcels of non-contiguous off-reservation trust lands in Meade County, South Dakota , northeast of the city of Sturgis . Its timbered ridges that extend into northwestern South Dakota are part of Custer National Forest and it is approximately 40 miles (64 km) east of the site of the 1876 Battle of the Little Bighorn . In March 2013, the Northern Cheyenne Tribe had 12,266 people enrolled citizens, of which about 6,012 resided on the reservation, [ incomplete short citation ] with approximately 91% of the population Native American (full or part blood quantum ) and 72.8% identifying as Cheyenne. Slightly more than a quarter of the population five years or older spoke a language other than English. Members of the Crow Tribe also live on the reservation. The tribal and government headquarters are located in Lame Deer , where they host the annual Northern Cheyenne powwow . Demographics Traditional Cheyenne spiritual culture, like most traditional Indigenous spiritual ways, values the peoples' connection to their landbase, and sees the land itself, as well as special sites like Bear Butte , as sacred. Numerous Cheyenne work as foresters and fire fighters. This spiritual perspective is evident in traditional communities like Lame Deer and Birney and when the 2006 vote on development coal and coalbed methane on the reservation split along modernist vs traditional lines. [ incomplete short citation ] A historical buffalo jump, burial sites of Cheyenne chiefs and spiritual leaders, the site of Custer 's last camp before the Battle of the Little Bighorn , the Cheyenne Indian Museum, Ten Bears Gallery, St. Labre Indian School , and the Ashland Powwow are sites of special interest in the Ashland area. The Northern Cheyenne are related to the Southern Cheyenne , who are located in Oklahoma . Following the Black Hills War and earlier conflicts in Colorado (see Sand Creek Massacre and Washita Massacre ), the Northern Cheyenne were forcibly moved to Oklahoma and restricted to lands of their southern relatives. Unable to acclimate swiftly to the heat of western Oklahoma ( Indian Territory at the time), having to grow their food instead of hunting or gathering as were their ways, and the brutal conditions in the barracks where they were held, the northerners quickly began dying. In desperation, a small band left

Francis Lewis Boulevard and exit 21, which connects to the Clearview Expressway (I-295) and its southern terminus. The parkway leaves Cunningham Park, entering the Bellerose section of Queens, entering exit 22, which connects to Union Turnpike via Stronghurst Avenue. The route then enters Alley Pond Park , where it interchanges with the Cross Island Parkway and Winchester Boulevard. After the interchange, the Grand Central passes west of Creedmoor Hospital , winding northeast into exit 24, which serves Little Neck Parkway before winding northeast to the Nassau County line in Little Neck . At this crossing, the parkway changes names to the Northern State Parkway , which continues east towards Hauppauge . History The Grand Central Parkway was first proposed in 1922, as a scenic drive along the high ground of east-central Queens. By the time construction began in 1931, it had been reconceived as extending northwestward to the Triborough Bridge, then in the planning stages, and connecting on the east with the Northern State Parkway, also in the planning stages, thereby among other things providing an easier route from the bridge to Jones Beach . The parkway was widened in 1961 in preparation for the 1964 New York World's Fair in Flushing Meadows–Corona Park . In 2010 construction began at Kew Gardens Interchange to improve traffic congestion. Formerly, the frontage road of the Grand Central between BQE and the RFK Bridge served as a truck route, since large trucks were not permitted on the parkway. Exemptions were provided for smaller trucks that conform with strict regulations on the section of the Grand Central that overlapped with I-278. In December 2017, the state concluded a $2.5 million project that lowered the roadbed of the section of the parkway that is concurrent with I-278. This section of I-278 now has a 14-foot (4.3 m) vertical clearance, which allows most trucks to stay on I-278. Exit list References External links Wikimedia Commons has media related to Grand Central Parkway . communities.summary:
**Title**: Jimmy Cricket Career & Life

**Summary**:  
Jimmy Cricket, born James Mulgrew in 1945, is a Northern Irish comedian famed for his clean, family-friendly humor and catchphrase “And there’s more.” Rising to fame in the 1970s, he starred in four TV series of *And There’s More* and BBC Radio 2’s *Jimmy’s Cricket Team*. After early jobs as a Red Coat and Pontins entertainer, he became a staple of UK variety, touring with acts like The Osmonds and Cannon & Ball, appearing on *Bullseye*, *The Good Old Days*, and multiple Royal Variety Shows. His trademark outfit—tailcoat, hat, and Wellington boots on the wrong feet—complements his “Irish logic” routines and letters from “Mammy.” Awarded a papal knighthood in 2015 for charity work, he lives in Lancashire with his wife; three of their four children pursued public careers, including comedian Katie and priest-author Frankie.

**Keywords**: Jimmy Cricket, clean comedy, And There’s More, Irish logic, papal knighthood

**Title**: Jimmy Cricket Career & Life

**Summary**:  
Jimmy Cricket, born James Mulgrew in 1945, is a Northern Irish comedian renowned for his clean, family-friendly humor and trademark comedic persona. Rising to fame in the 1970s, he starred in multiple television and radio series, including *And There’s More* and *Jimmy’s Cricket Team*, and became a staple of British variety entertainment. His act features “Irish logic,” letters from his “Mammy,” and signature Wellington boots on the wrong feet. Beyond comedy, he has supported numerous charities, received a papal knighthood, and remains active in touring and public life.

**Keywords**:  
Jimmy Cricket, clean comedy, And There’s More, Irish logic, papal knighthood

**Title**: Gordon Burns Broadcasting Career

**Summary**: Gordon Burns is a veteran Northern Irish journalist and broadcaster best known for hosting ITV’s game show *The Krypton Factor* for 18 years and anchoring BBC’s *North West Tonight* from 1997 to 2011. His career spans decades across both television and radio, beginning at the *Belfast Telegraph* and Ulster Television, later moving to Granada TV where he worked on *World in Action* and *Granada Reports*. After retiring from TV news, he hosted Sunday morning radio shows for BBC Manchester and Lancashire and contributed to BBC Radio 6 Music. Burns has also presented various game shows and current affairs programs across ITV and BBC.

**Keywords**: Gordon Burns, The Krypton Factor, North West Tonight, BBC Radio, Granada Television

**Title**: Briana Corrigan Music Career

**Summary**:  
Briana Corrigan is a Northern Irish singer best known as a vocalist for The Beautiful South from 1988 to 1992, contributing to their chart-topping single "A Little Time." After leaving the band over creative and ethical differences, she launched a solo career, releasing the well-received album *When My Arms Wrap You Round* in 1996. She later returned to music with independent releases and, until 2022, taught singing in Abu Dhabi.

**Keywords**:  
Briana Corrigan, The Beautiful South, solo album, Northern Irish singer, music career

**Title:**  
Garth Ennis: War Comics & Anti-Superhero Voice  

**Summary:**  
Garth Ennis is a Northern Irish writer renowned for war-themed and anti-superhero comics. Influenced by British war stories and mid-1980s mature comics, he subverts superhero tropes—most famously in “Punisher Kills the Marvel Universe” and “The Boys”—while praising grounded characters like Punisher and Nick Fury. His creator-owned output via Avatar, Dynamite, and TKO spans WWII sagas (“Sara,” “Partisan,” “Stringbags”), horror (“Crossed”), and satire, consistently emphasizing human-scale conflict over fantastical heroics.  

**Keywords:**  
war comics, anti-superhero, Punisher, The Boys, creator-owned

**Title**: Northern Cheyenne Reservation Bands

**Summary**: The text details the major historical and present-day Cheyenne bands settled on the Northern Cheyenne Indian Reservation in southeastern Montana, including the Ononeo’o (mixed Arikara-Mandan-Cheyenne), Totoemanaho (“Backward Clan”), Vóhpoométaneo’o (“White River People”), and Northern Só’taeo’o (Suhtai). Each band’s unique origin, traditional territories in the Black Hills and Powder River Country, intertribal marriages with Lakota, and current reservation locales such as Busby, Birney, Ashland, and Lame Deer are described. The passage also notes the tribe’s higher-education hub, Chief Dull Knife College in Lame Deer, which serves as a community and land-grant institution helping graduates transition to four-year universities.

**Keywords**: Cheyenne bands, Northern Cheyenne Reservation, Suhtai, White River Cheyenne, Chief Dull Knife College

**Title**: Cedric the Entertainer Career Highlights

**Summary**:  
Cedric Antonio Kyles, known professionally as Cedric the Entertainer, is a multifaceted American comedian, actor, and television host. He rose to fame through stand-up comedy, notably as part of *The Original Kings of Comedy* alongside Steve Harvey, Bernie Mac, and D.L. Hughley, which was later adapted into a Spike Lee film. Cedric gained widespread recognition for his roles in *The Steve Harvey Show*, the *Barbershop* film series, and as a voice actor in animated hits like *Ice Age*, *Madagascar*, and *Planes*. He has hosted several TV shows, including *Who Wants to Be a Millionaire*, and starred in sitcoms like *The Soul Man* and *The Neighborhood*. His career spans decades and includes awards, voice roles, film appearances, and even a brief stint in professional wrestling and auto racing.

**Keywords**:  
Cedric the Entertainer, stand-up comedy, The Original Kings of Comedy, Barbershop, voice acting

**Title**: Kyle Lafferty Football Career

**Summary**:  
Kyle Lafferty is a Northern Irish striker whose career spans top-flight clubs across the UK, Europe, and lower-tier Scottish football. After 89 games for Burnley, he joined Rangers for £3.25 million in 2008, winning three Scottish Premier League titles, a Scottish Cup, and two League Cups. Post-Rangers, he played for FC Sion, Palermo (Serie B champions 2013-14), Norwich City, and had loan spells at Çaykur Rizespor and Birmingham City. Later moves included Heart of Midlothian, two stints at Kilmarnock, Sunderland, Reggina, Anorthosis Famagusta, Linfield, and ultimately Johnstone Burgh in Scotland’s seventh tier, where he captained them to the 2024-25 Scottish Junior Cup. Internationally, Lafferty has 80+ caps for Northern Ireland, scoring 20 goals—second only to David Healy—and starred in UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying with seven goals.

**Keywords**:  
Rangers, Northern Ireland, Palermo, Kilmarnock, Johnstone Burgh

**Title**: Northern Cheyenne Reservation Heritage  

**Summary**:  
The Northern Cheyenne Indian Reservation in southeastern Montana encompasses 690 square miles and is home to about 6,000 citizens of the federally recognized Northern Cheyenne Tribe, who maintain strong spiritual ties to their land and traditional culture. Formed after the 1878 Northern Cheyenne Exodus from Oklahoma, the reservation’s communities—Lame Deer, Busby, Ashland, and Birney—center on education, including Chief Dull Knife College and St. Labre Indian School, while economic activity involves tribal government, forestry, ranching, and coal-adjacent work. Historic bands such as the Notameohmésêhese (“Northern Eaters”) and Northern Só’taeo’o continue to shape political and cultural life, and sacred sites like Bear Butte, buffalo jumps, and battle-related landmarks anchor Cheyenne identity. Notable figures—chiefs Little Wolf and Two Moons, flutist Joseph Fire Crow, and linguist Marie Sanchez—exemplify the tribe’s enduring contributions to Indigenous leadership, arts, and scholarship.  

**Keywords**:  
Northern Cheyenne, Montana reservation, cultural preservation, tribal education, spiritual land ties

**Title**: Grace O'Malley’s Resistance to English Rule  

**Summary**:  
Grace O'Malley, the 16th-century Gaelic chieftain and sea-captain, fiercely defended her autonomy against expanding English authority in Connacht. After English forces jailed her son Tibbott-ne-Long and half-brother Dónal, she sailed to London and secured their release by personally petitioning Queen Elizabeth I, negotiating a tenuous peace while retaining her lands and maritime power. Throughout her life she led clan forces, seized castles, and outmaneuvered regional enemies, earning both notoriety from English officials and legendary status in Irish folklore.  

**Keywords**:  
Grace O'Malley, Elizabeth I, Connacht rebellion, Irish piracy, Tudor conquest

**Title**: Barry Andrews Music Career  

**Summary**:  
Barry Andrews is an English keyboardist, singer, and songwriter who co-founded the long-running post-punk band Shriekback after early stints with XTC and Robert Fripp’s League of Gentlemen. His output spans four decades, including 18 Shriekback albums, solo projects such as the experimental Stic Basin and Haunted Box of Switches series, and collaborations with Iggy Pop, Brian Eno, and others. During a mid-career hiatus from music he pursued 3-D design and ran an art gallery, returning to steady releases on his own Shriekprods label. Andrews continues to perform and record, issuing Contaminated Pop in 2019 and the 2025 album Monument.  

**Keywords**:  
Shriekback, XTC, post-punk, experimental electronica, solo discography

**Title**: Irish Plantation Measure System  

**Summary**:  
From the 16th-century plantations until the 19th century, Ireland employed a distinct set of land and distance units—Irish or plantation measure—based on a 21-foot perch rather than the English 16½-foot rod, yielding linear units ~27% longer and area units ~62% larger. Although the 1824 Weights and Measures Act imposed imperial (statute) units, Irish measure persisted in local surveys, milestones, property deeds, and even some Acts of Parliament, producing legal and practical confusion well into the 20th century. Place-names like Sixmilebridge and Fivemiletown still record the old Irish-mile distances, while colloquial speech retains “an Irish mile” to mean a long way.

**Keywords**: Irish acre, plantation perch, statute conversion, milestones, measurement history

**Title:** Grand Central Parkway Route

**Summary:**  
The Grand Central Parkway is a 14.61-mile controlled-access parkway in New York City that runs from the Triborough Bridge in Queens to the Queens–Nassau County line, where it becomes the Northern State Parkway. It passes key landmarks such as LaGuardia Airport, Citi Field, and Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, and intersects with major routes like the Long Island Expressway and the Van Wyck Expressway. The parkway is notable for allowing limited truck traffic on its I-278 overlap and features a unique trailblazer design. Originally proposed in 1922, it was widened for the 1964 World’s Fair and has undergone recent upgrades to improve traffic flow.

**Keywords:**  
Grand Central Parkway, Queens, LaGuardia Airport, Northern State Parkway, I-278

**Title**: 1997 Argentine Grand Prix

**Summary**: The 1997 Argentine Grand Prix, the 600th World Championship race, was won from pole by Jacques Villeneuve, with Eddie Irvine second and rookie Ralf Schumacher taking his first podium in third. The event was marked by multiple first-lap collisions that triggered a Safety Car and eliminated several front-runners, including Michael Schumacher and David Coulthard. Mid-field battles saw Pedro Diniz surge from last to 11th, while both Jordan drivers retired with engine failures after strong runs. Post-race controversy arose when organizers flew the Irish tricolour for Northern Irish driver Irvine, prompting loyalist backlash and FIA insistence on future use of the Union Jack.

**Keywords**: 1997 Argentine GP, Jacques Villeneuve, Eddie Irvine, Ralf Schumacher, podium controversy

**Title**: Barry Murphy Football Career

**Summary**: Barry Murphy was an Irish soccer player active in the 1980s who earned one cap for the national team under Jack Charlton. He played for several League of Ireland clubs, most notably Bohemians where he captained the team, made 148 league appearances, scored 7 goals, and played in 6 European matches. After leaving Bohemians in 1988, he joined Shamrock Rovers where he made 91 appearances and scored 2 goals.

**Keywords**: Irish footballer, League of Ireland, Bohemians, Shamrock Rovers, national team

**Title**: Cheyenne Military Societies

**Summary**:  
The Cheyenne military societies are six traditional warrior organizations—Fox, Elk, Shield, Bowstring, Dog, and Contrary—that serve as key pillars of tribal governance alongside the Council of Forty-four. Each society has distinct roles, rituals, and branches, such as the Dog Warriors (Dog Soldiers) and the Contrary Warriors who ride backward into battle. Over time, some societies like the Bowstring Men split into Northern Crazy Dogs and Southern Wolf Warriors, while others like the Red Shields persist only among the Northern Cheyenne. These societies maintain discipline, lead hunts and ceremonies, and provide military leadership, with women warriors like Ehyophsta and Mochi also recognized in specific warrior societies.

**Keywords**: Cheyenne warrior societies, Dog Soldiers, Contrary Warriors, tribal governance, military leadership

**Title**: 2001 Monaco Grand Prix Drama  

**Summary**:  
Michael Schumacher dominated the 2001 Monaco Grand Prix, setting a new lap record and securing his fourth win of the season amid high attrition that saw only ten of 22 starters finish. The race was marked by a tense 35-lap feud between McLaren’s David Coulthard and Arrows’ Enrique Bernoldi, whose defensive driving triggered post-race threats from McLaren management and driver-association complaints. Multiple retirements—Panis, Häkkinen, Trulli, Fisichella, Frentzen and others—shuffled the order and promoted Jaguar’s Eddie Irvine to the team’s first podium in third place. Ferrari’s one-two finish extended Schumacher’s championship lead to 12 points and the team’s constructors’ cushion to 32.  

**Keywords**: Monaco Grand Prix 2001, Schumacher victory, Coulthard-Bernoldi feud, high attrition, Irvine podium

**Title**: Eddie Irvine’s F1 Career

**Summary**:  
Eddie Irvine’s Formula One journey spanned a decade, highlighted by his role as Michael Schumacher’s Ferrari teammate and his near-miss at the 1999 Drivers’ Championship. After solid but unspectacular seasons with Jordan and Ferrari, 1999 became his breakthrough year: four wins, the championship lead after Schumacher’s injury, and a title-deciding finale in Japan where he lost to Mika Häkkinen by two points while securing Ferrari’s first Constructors’ crown since 1983. From 2000-2002 he captained the fledgling Jaguar team, scoring their first podium at Monaco 2001 but enduring reliability woes that left him 13th and 11th in successive standings. Known for blunt talk and playboy flair, Irvine nonetheless insisted his life was “90 % work,” raced under a neutral shamrock flag to defuse Northern-Irish politics, and was awarded the Hawthorn Memorial Trophy for best British/Commonwealth driver in 1999.

**Keywords**:  
Ferrari, 1999 title fight, Jaguar, playboy image, Hawthorn Trophy

**Title**: Detroit's Grand Boulevard

**Summary**:  
Grand Boulevard is an 11-mile ring road encircling central Detroit, conceived in 1876 and completed in 1913 as the city’s intended expansion boundary. Championed by Mayor Hazen S. Pingree, the landscaped thoroughfare was later surpassed by rapid 20th-century growth and now features honorary names like Berry Gordy Jr. Boulevard near the Motown Museum and General Motors Boulevard in the New Center district. Its route became the namesake “Grand Belt” streetcar and bus lines until transit service ended in 2009, and portions were re-routed in 1981 for GM’s Poletown plant after a landmark eminent-domain case.

**Keywords**:  
Grand Boulevard, Detroit history, eminent domain, Grand Belt line, Motown Museum

**Title**: Cheyenne Council of Forty-Four Governance  

**Summary**:  
The Council of Forty-four is the central civil authority of the Cheyenne, formed from four chiefs of each of the ten bands plus four revered “Old Man” chiefs who serve ten-year terms. Chiefs, chosen by the council itself, renounce military-society ties and rely on moral authority to manage tribal-wide diplomacy and peace, while rotating military societies handle discipline and defense. The 1864 Sand Creek Massacre killed eight council members and other peace advocates, shattering the traditional clan-based succession and shifting power toward the militant Dog Soldiers, who rejected accommodation with whites. Despite this rupture, the Cheyenne still maintain the Council of Forty-four, with contemporary peace chiefs active in Native governance.  

**Keywords**: Cheyenne, Council of Forty-four, Sand Creek Massacre, Dog Soldiers, tribal governance

**Title**: Sheridan, Wyoming Cultural Heritage  

**Summary**:  
Sheridan blends cowboy rodeo traditions with American Indian pageantry, anchored by the 1931 Sheridan WYO Rodeo and the 1953 Miss Indian America Pageant. Historic ranches, museums, and 10 National Register sites—such as Trail End mansion and the Brinton Museum—preserve Western and Native art and history. Annual events, public art like the Wyoming Horse sculpture, and venues like the Carriage House Theater sustain a vibrant cultural scene that inspired Craig Johnson’s Longmire novels.  

**Keywords**:  
Sheridan WYO Rodeo, Western heritage, American Indian culture, historic sites, Brinton Museum

**Title**: Beautiful South's "A Little Time"

**Summary**:  
"A Little Time" is the 1990 chart-topping single by English pop-rock band the Beautiful South, taken from their second album *Choke*. The duet, sung by Dave Hemingway and Briana Corrigan, became the group's only UK number-one hit and also reached the top 20 across several European countries. Songwriters Paul Heaton and David Rotheray frame it as an unconventional love song about everyday relationship tensions, a theme echoed in its award-winning music video depicting a couple's domestic fight. Critics praised its gentle country-tinged arrangement and emotional resonance, and the video—directed by Nick Brandt—won British Video of the Year at the 1991 Brit Awards.

**Keywords**: Beautiful South, A Little Time, UK number-one, Brit Awards, relationship ballad

**Title**: 2001 Monaco Grand Prix Technical Updates

**Summary**:  
Ahead of the 2001 Monaco Grand Prix, teams introduced extensive aerodynamic and safety upgrades—Prost, Benetton, and Jaguar revised wings, undertrays, and crash structures, while Arrows and Jordan debuted elevated nose-wing devices that were later banned for regulatory infringement. Practice sessions saw dry conditions and multiple incidents, with Häkkinen ultimately setting the fastest lap. Championship leader Michael Schumacher, after inheriting pole from Coulthard’s stalled car, dominated the race to secure his fourth win of the season and extend Ferrari’s Constructors’ lead. Concerns over electronic launch-control reliability prompted Jordan to revert to manual starts, and the FIA warned of severe penalties for mis-configured systems.

**Keywords**: Monaco Grand Prix 2001, aerodynamic upgrades, launch control, Michael Schumacher, FIA regulations

**Title**: Eddie Irvine's Racing Career

**Summary**: Eddie Irvine, born in Northern Ireland in 1965, rose from Formula Ford to become a Formula One front-runner, finishing runner-up in the 1999 World Drivers' Championship with Ferrari and winning four Grands Prix. After early success in junior series and a controversial 1993 F1 debut with Jordan, he moved to Ferrari in 1996, scoring 22 podiums and narrowly missing the 1999 title. He later joined Jaguar, taking their first podium in 2001, and retired in 2002. Post-racing, Irvine became a media personality and property investor.

**Keywords**: Eddie Irvine, Formula One, Ferrari, 1999 Championship, Jordan

**Title**: Eddie Irvine's Formula One Career

**Summary**:  
The text chronicles Eddie Irvine’s Formula One tenure, focusing on his 2001-2002 seasons with Jaguar where he scored his last podium and clinched final championship points despite reliability issues and internal friction. It details contract disputes, management changes, and on-track incidents, followed by his post-F1 life encompassing media work, legal victories, business ventures, and occasional legal troubles. Earlier Jordan years (1994-1995) are also referenced, highlighting bans, controversies, and Le Mans success that framed his racing persona.

**Keywords**:  
Eddie Irvine, Jaguar F1, Formula One, post-racing career, Jordan Grand Prix

**Title**: Sheridan, Wyoming Heritage

**Summary**:  
Sheridan, Wyoming, a historic railroad and coal town nestled between Yellowstone and Mount Rushmore, evolved from 19th-century frontier outpost to diversified modern service hub. Waves of Polish, Italian, Greek, German, Mexican, Japanese, English and South-Asian immigrants fueled agriculture, mining and dude-ranch tourism, leaving a multicultural legacy celebrated in local memory. The city’s economy shifted from coal and sugar-beet processing to healthcare, education, manufacturing and recreation, supported by nearly 400 nonprofits and guest-ranch heritage. Notable natives and residents include governors, a U.S. senator, Buffalo Bill Cody, Best Buy’s ex-CEO, and even a visit by Queen Elizabeth II. Today Sheridan anchors a tri-county region of 18,000 residents with a semi-arid climate and strong community institutions.

**Keywords**:  
Sheridan history, immigrant heritage, coal railroad, dude ranch tourism, Wyoming culture
